Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, heart pounding as I watched my stepbrother tighten his helmet, eyes fixed on the steep, cracked ramp. He grinned at me, determined to land the trick he’d been practicing for weeks. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, to make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But my phone buzzed again—my boyfriend’s name lighting up the screen. We’d argued every night this week about money, and he wanted to talk, to finally resolve things. I could hear his voice in my head, pleading for my attention, for us to fix what was broken. But my stepbrother was already rolling toward the ramp, and I knew he needed me to watch out for him, to be there in case something went wrong. I felt torn in two, pulled by the weight of both roles—one demanding I stay, the other begging me to go. My hands shook as I tried to decide which expectation I would have to let down.
